channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Out-Faking the Fakers: Chinese Librarian Proud of Forged Masters
item.description: A former librarian at the Guangzhou Academy of Fine Arts has described in court how his discovery of forged master paintings in the school’s collection inspired him to make his own copies — and do a better job.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paintings on preview for an auction in Hong Kong including works by Zhang Daqian (second from right) and Qi Baishi (left, second from left and third from left). Xiao Yuan said he copied paintings by both masters.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Turmoil in China’s Stock Markets Takes a Psychic Toll
item.description: Amid the recent turbulence in China’s stock markets, doctors have reported a surge in what they are calling “stock market anxiety syndrome.”
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and VANESSA PIAO
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investors following the ups and downs of the stock markets at a brokerage house in Beijing.

item.title: China Mounts Crackdown Against Human Rights Lawyers
item.description: More than 200 lawyers and associates have been detained on accusations of exploiting cases to enrich themselves and to attack the Communist Party.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I used to think being a lawyer was just a tool to make money,” said Yu Wensheng, 48, a commercial lawyer whose recent arrest nudged him into the ranks of human rights defenders. “But now I believe we have a greater mission to change a broken system.”

item.title: Rome Journal: Romans Put Little Faith in Mayor as Their Ancient City Degrades
item.description: Ignazio Marino is seen as an honest leader. But many question whether that is enough in the face of crumbling services, a declining standard of living and government scandal.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trash littered a street in the historic neighborhood of Trastevere in Rome.

item.title: Alexis Tsipras and His Syriza Party Clash as Greece Faces Another Deadline
item.description: Parliament must approve a package of financial and judicial changes before midnight to keep negotiations on track for the bailout of about $94 billion.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:description: Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos of Greece in Parliament in Athens on Wednesday, before a midnight deadline for approving a package of creditor-mandated measures.

item.title: Suicide Bombing at Afghan Market Kills Dozens
item.description: The attack took place in Almar, a district that has been the site of fierce fighting in recent months as the Taliban have extended a wave of violence north.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and AHMAD SHAKIB

item.title: Washington Post Files U.N. Petition to Seek Release of Reporter Jason Rezaian
item.description: By submitting a petition to a human rights panel, the newspaper sought to raise pressure on the Iranian government over the correspondent’s year-old incarceration.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Jason Rezaian and his wife Yeganeh Salehi in 2013.

item.title: Suicide Bomber in Suruc Is Said to Be a Turk With Possible Ties to ISIS
item.description: Seyh Abdurrahman Alagoz, a 20-year-old university student who had recently returned from Syria, was identified through DNA testing, according to the Turkish news media.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: The riot police clashed with protesters on Tuesday in Istanbul after a deadly suicide attack the day before in Suruc, Turkey.

item.title: Provision in Iran Accord Is Challenged by Some Nuclear Experts
item.description: Some experts have expressed skepticism over a provision in the nuclear accord that gives Iran 24 days to grant inspectors access to suspicious sites.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Andrew G. Walder on ‘China Under Mao’
item.description: In his latest book, Mr. Walder argues that Mao lurched from crisis to crisis, inspired less by a new vision of Communism than a simplistic understanding of Stalinist ideology.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: Andrew G. Walder has written extensively about life in Maoist China.

item.title: Quran Fragments, Said to Date From Time of Muhammad, Are Found in Britain
item.description: The probable age of the manuscript, found at the University of Birmingham’s library, would place its writing within a few years of Islam’s founding.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The ancient fragments of the Quran are believed to be at least 1,370 years old, potentially placing its writing within a few years of the founding of Islam.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Transforming the Fight Against Poverty in India
item.description: Greater access to banks, unique ID cards and mobile phones are making it easier for the government to transfer cash to the poor.
item.dc:creator: SIDDHARTH GEORGE and ARVIND SUBRAMANIAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Russia’s Scientists Fall Silent
item.description: The Kremlin, suspicious of the West's democratic values, now finds the risks of cooperation to be too great.
item.dc:creator: HARLEY D. BALZER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: A Return to the Malaysian Village
item.description: Rampant urbanization has hurt small towns. It is time to rejuvenate them.
item.dc:creator: TASH AW

item.title: Ai Weiwei, Chinese Artist and Provocateur, Is Given Back His Passport
item.description: Alternately lauded or judged an irritant by Beijing, Mr. Ai had been barred from travel since 2011, when he was detained on suspicion of tax evasion.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Afghan Security Forces Struggle Just to Maintain Stalemate
item.description: With months of heavy fighting still ahead, 2015 is already shaping up to be worse than last year for the Afghan Army and the national police.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan national police recruits lined up at a shooting range during a training session in Kabul in 2014. Desertion has been a problem among the police and the army.

item.title: Is This the End of Christianity in the Middle East?
item.description: ISIS and other extremist movements across the region are enslaving, killing and uprooting Christians, with no aid in sight.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ELIZA GRISWOLD
item.media:credit: Peter van Agtmael/Magnum, for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue destroyed by ISIS last summer in a 13th-century church in Telskuf, Iraq.

item.title: Iran Deal Looms as U.S. Defense Secretary Meets With Netanyahu
item.description: A face-to-face session between Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday was fraught with tension.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter, left, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel before their meeting in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Denmark: Nazi Hunter Urges Inquiry of Dane, 90
item.description: A leading Nazi hunter has asked Denmark to investigate a 90-year-old Dane suspected of being involved in the mass murder of Jews in Belarus.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Maldives: Vice President Is Impeached in Absentia
item.description: Parliament in the Maldives voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to impeach Vice President Mohamed Jameel after accusing him of dereliction of duties.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
